results.title: Glen Keane interview with Emma McRae
results.brief_description: Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as: ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. In this interview, Emma McRae, ACMI Exhibitions Curator, speaks to Glen about his never-ending passion for drawing and what inspires him to create such unforgettable characters as The Beast and Ariel. Glen also talks about the changes in animation from hand drawn to digital.
results.description: Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as: ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. In this interview, Emma McRae, ACMI Exhibitions Curator, speaks to Glen about his never-ending passion for drawing and what inspires him to create such unforgettable characters as The Beast and Ariel. Glen also talks about the changes in animation from hand drawn to digital.

In this interview, Emma McRae, ACMI Exhibitions Curator, speaks to Glen about his never-ending passion for drawing and what inspires him to create such unforgettable characters as The Beast and Ariel. Glen also talks about the changes in animation from hand drawn to digital.

results.title: The Power of the situation
results.creator_credit: Tuggelin Yourgrau, David Espar and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
This program looks at the ways in which people are influenced by leaders, groups and society - at social psychology. Psychological experiments by Lewin and Milgram, inspired by the extreme cruelty of the Nazi regime, suggest that, given the same circumstances, a powerful leader, peer group pressure, an extraordinary situation, everyone is capable of the same extremes of good or evil behaviour. Once the situation no longer exists we return to our “normal” selves. Archival film of these experiments is included.

results.title: Testing and intelligence
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
How smart are you? Can the richness and complexity of intelligence be summed up in a number? and what is the effect of this number on you? In this program Philip Zimbardo looks at the controversial area of psychometrics, of cognitive, intelligence tests and psychological assessment tests. He introduces the different tests established by Binet, Galton, Wexler and others and stresses the extreme care that must be taken in administering and using the tests. He concludes by summarising the nature versus nurture argument which has been provoked by testing.

results.title: Why?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Tehree Gordon
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Tehree says she is an ordinary Australian, though she was a recipient of the Senior Australian of the Year Award in 2004. In this story, Tehree talks about her passion for wildlife from an early age leading to her founding Jirrahlinga Koala and Wildlife Sanctuary with her partner Hamish. The sanctuary has provided work opportunities and enrichment to people living with disabilities and the elderly.

results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Jock Noble, CEO of Diversity@work Australia, talks about the impact having Polio had on his childhood and how that has subsequently shaped his career in helping companies to strengthen through diversity in their workforce.

results.title: Understanding research
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
What methods do psychologists use to probe human nature? In this program, Philip Zimbardo explains the methods of scientific research including the principles of laboratory experiments, surveys, interviews and psychological tests. In doing so, he considers the validity of lie detector tests, questions the reality of psychic powers and outlines the power of the “placebo” effect when a patient’s condition improves simply because they believe their treatment is doing them good.
results.description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
What methods do psychologists use to probe human nature? In this program, Philip Zimbardo explains the methods of scientific research including the principles of laboratory experiments, surveys, interviews and psychological tests. results.title: My Banquet...
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Chey Scovell
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Chey Scovell recounts his childhood growing up as an Australian born in Malaysia and the last four years of schooling spent in Papua New Guinea. He tells of the culture shock he experienced when returning back to Australia.

results.title: Doors Will Open
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Rajani Shrestha
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Rajani Shrestha moved to Melbourne from Nepal in 1992 with her husband and son. Rajani recounts the struggle she faced to find meaningful work in a new country. She tells of her journey which eventually led to her working at AMES Australia.
results.description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Rajani Shrestha moved to Melbourne from Nepal in 1992 with her husband and son. Rajani recounts the struggle she faced to find meaningful work in a new country. She tells of her journey which eventually led to her working at AMES Australia.
